intro: Muilla purpusii, commonly known as the Mexican moonflower, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the nightshade family, Solanaceae, and is known for its large, white, fragrant flowers that open at night. The plant typically grows in tropical and subtropical regions, preferring well-drained soil and full sun to partial shade. Its leaves are broad and heart-shaped, and it produces small, berry-like fruits that contain the seeds. Muilla purpusii is cultivated for its ornamental value and has cultural significance in some indigenous communities.
